start.title: Morocco

start.brief_description: The Foreign Legion marches into Mogador with booze and women in mind just as singer Amy Jolly arrives from Paris to work at Lo Tinto’s cabaret. That night, insouciant legionnaire Tom Brown catches her inimitably seductive, tuxedo-clad act.

constellations_other.name: Marlene Dietrich: queering gender onscreen
constellations_other.description: Marlene Dietrich is an icon of queer style – from her proud bisexuality to her scandalous decision to wear a tuxedo on the red carpet. This constellation explores androgyny, gender non-conformity and drag on screen in the century since Dietrich's performance in Morocco (1930).

end.title: The Blue Angel
end.creator_credit: Josef von Sternberg, Tihamer Varady, Erich Pommer, UFA, Emil Hasler, Carl Winston, Carl Zuckmayer, Karl Vollmöller and Robert Liebmann
end.brief_description: Prim professor Immanuel Rath finds some of his students ogling photos of cabaret performer Lola Lola and visits a local club, The Blue Angel, to catch them there. When the teacher himself falls for Lola Lola, life becomes difficult.

links.description: Marlene Dietrich shot to international acclaim in Germany’s first feature-length talkie The Blue Angel directed by Josef von Sternberg, who brought Dietrich to Paramount. Dietrich and Sternberg would work on seven films together before their collaboration ended in 1935.

results.name: All about Agnes
results.description: Belgian director Agnes Varda was the only female director in the French New Wave movement and is known for her long career across influential documentary and dramas, and for her trademark humour, curiosity and insight.

key_work.title: Agnès Varda in Les Glaneurs et La Glaneuse (The Gleaners and I)
key_work.credit_line: Courtesy Zeitgeist Films / Everett Collection Inc. / Alamy
key_work.brief_description: Dziga Vertov’s kino-pravda (“film truth”) concept was premised on the camera’s ability to reveal truth. It inspired both cinéma vérité and direct cinema, which informed Albert and David Maysles’ intimate ‘fly-on-the-wall’ style and Agnès Varda’s intimate portraits of society and herself.

end.title: Cléo from 5 to 7
end.creator_credit: Agnès Varda, Alyette Samazeuilh, Carlo Ponti, Georges de Beauregard, Ciné-Tamaris, Rome Paris Films and Bernard Evein
end.brief_description: Agnès Varda eloquently captures Paris in the sixties with this real-time portrait of a singer set adrift in the city as she awaits test results of a biopsy. A chronicle of the minutes of one woman’s life, Cléo from 5 to 7 is a spirited mix of vivid vérité and melodrama, featuring a score by Michel Legrand and cameos by Jean-Luc Godard and Anna Karina.

links.description: Varda’s early film Cleo from 5 to 7 is a portrait of a woman in Paris, portraying everyday experiences to reveal a character’s inner life. It features cameos by Jean-Luc Godard and Anna Karina.

end.title: La Pointe-Courte
end.creator_credit: Agnès Varda and Ciné-Tamaris
end.brief_description: A penetrating study of a marriage on the rocks, set against the backdrop of a small Mediterranean fishing village. Both a stylized depiction of the complicated relationship between a married couple and a documentary-like look at the daily struggles of the inhabitants of Sète in the South of France.

constellations_other.name: All about Agnes
constellations_other.description: Belgian director Agnes Varda was the only female director in the French New Wave movement and is known for her long career across influential documentary and dramas, and for her trademark humour, curiosity and insight.

links.description: Before she made Cleo from 5 to 7, Varda’s first film was La Pointe Courte, a stylistic precursor to the French New Wave. Varda used a combination of documentary and fiction, which became a recurring theme in her work.

end.title: Hiroshima Mon Amour
end.creator_credit: Alain Resnais, Gerard Collery, Anatole Dauman, Samy Halfon, Argos Films, Como Films, Daiei Film, Pathé Entertainment, Pathé Overseas, Lucilla Mussini, Mayo, Minoru Esaka, Petri and Marguerite Duras

video_links.name: Hiroshima Mon Amour | Trailer | New Release

end.brief_description: The deep conversation between a Japanese architect and a French actress forms the basis of this celebrated French film, considered one of the vanguard productions of the French New Wave. Set in Hiroshima after the end of World War II, the couple — lovers turned friends — recount, over many hours, previous romances and life experiences. The two intertwine their stories about the past with pondering the devastation wrought by the atomic bomb dropped on the city.

links.description: La Pointe Courte preceded the French New Wave films, such as Hiroshima Mon Amour, directed by Alain Resnais – who also edited Varda’s first film.

end.brief_description: Pierrot escapes his boring society and travels from Paris to the Mediterranean Sea with Marianne, a girl chased by hit-men from Algeria. They lead an unorthodox life, always on the run.

constellations_other.description: Explore how a 1903 western changed the course of filmmaking and videogames by breaking the fourth wall.

links.description: Directed by Jean-Luc Godard and starring Anna Karina, Pierrot le fou is one of eight films the couple made together during their marriage and after, with Karina frequently referred to as Godard’s muse.

start.title: The Beaches of Agnès
start.creator_credit: Agnès Varda, ARTE France Cinéma, Ciné-Tamaris and Franckie Diago
start.brief_description: Filmmaking icon Agnès Varda, the award-winning director regarded by many as the grandmother of the French new wave, turns the camera on herself with this unique autobiographical documentary. Composed of film excerpts and elaborate dramatic re-creations, Varda’s self-portrait recounts the highs and lows of her professional career, the many friendships that affected her life and her longtime marriage to cinematic giant Jacques Demy.

end.creator_credit: Jacques Demy, Jacqueline Moreau, Gilbert de Goldschmidt, Mag Bodard, Pierre Lazareff, Beta Film, Madeleine Films, Parc Film and Bernard Evein
end.brief_description: This simple romantic tragedy begins in 1957. Guy Foucher, a 20-year-old French auto mechanic, has fallen in love with 17-year-old Geneviève Emery, an employee in her widowed mother’s chic but financially embattled umbrella shop.

constellations_other.name: All about Agnes
constellations_other.description: Belgian director Agnes Varda was the only female director in the French New Wave movement and is known for her long career across influential documentary and dramas, and for her trademark humour, curiosity and insight.

links.description: In 1962, Varda married director Jacques Demy, most well known for his musical The Umbrellas of Cherboug. The couple remained together until Demy’s death in 1990, and his absence is revealed in photographs in Varda’s autobiographical film.

start.title: Aladdin
start.creator_credit: John Musker, Ron Clements, Walt Disney Animation Studios, Walt Disney Pictures, R.S. vander Wende, Ted Elliott, Terry Rossio, Brian Pimental, Burny Mattinson, Chris Sanders, Daan Jippes, Darrell Rooney, David Scott Smith, Francis Glebas, James Fujii, Kevin Harkey, Kevin Lima, Kirk Hanson, Larry Leker, Patrick A. Ventura, Rebecca Reese, Roger Allers and Sue C. Nichols
start.brief_description: Princess Jasmine grows tired of being forced to remain in the palace, so she sneaks out into the marketplace, in disguise, where she meets street-urchin Aladdin. The couple falls in love, although Jasmine may only marry a prince. After being thrown in jail, Aladdin becomes embroiled in a plot to find a mysterious lamp, with which the evil Jafar hopes to rule the land.

constellations_other.name: Cautionary tales and magic lantern projectors
constellations_other.description: Early magic lantern projections depicted cautionary religious scenes and fairytales, just like cinema did in its infancy.

links.description: Popular films such as The Story of the Kelly Gang would regularly tour the country via travelling distributors. At times films would be re-edited to remove scenes that might be bothersome to different audiences, censoring the film’s original narratives.

end.title: Titanic
end.creator_credit: James Cameron, Deborah Lynn Scott, Jon Landau, 20th Century Fox, Lightstorm Entertainment, Paramount, Peter Lamont and John Bruno
end.brief_description: 101-year-old Rose DeWitt Bukater tells the story of her life aboard the Titanic, 84 years later. A young Rose boards the ship with her mother and fiancé. Meanwhile, Jack Dawson and Fabrizio De Rossi win third-class tickets aboard the ship. Rose tells the whole story from Titanic’s departure through to its death—on its first and last voyage—on April 15, 1912.

constellations_other.name: Faking history
constellations_other.description: The Great takes a creative approach to its historical characters and settings that is mirrored in its costumes - this war dress might have a classic silhouette, but the grimy pearlescent fabric and striking oxblood detailing is completely modern. Faking history is a time-honoured tradition in film, from historical fiction to propaganda.

constellations_other.name: Quiet luxury, loud transformations
constellations_other.description: In The Dressmaker, Gertrude (Sarah Snook) transforms from 'dowdy' to elegant when she attends a dance in this dress. It's a popular cinema trope that shows how characters develop, but the 'makeover' trope isn't always a positive.

constellations_other.name: From queer period romances to surrealistic worlds

links.description: James Cameron’s Titanic also faced cuts when a scene featuring Kate Winslet’s exposed breasts was deemed culturally insensitive to China’s ban on pornographic content. Cameron felt it was better to extend the cultural impact of the film and so cut the scene for the Chinese release.

constellations_other.name: Jedda: Uneven ground, the road to on-screen diversity
constellations_other.description: Jedda was the first fully funded Australian feature to be shot on colour film. It was also the first Australian film with Aboriginal actors in lead roles, however, it reflects a deeply problematic time in Australian history.

constellations_other.name: Connecting through film
constellations_other.description: Film acts like a time capsule to our collective past. Capturing our most treasured moments with family has never been more accessible, with technology right at our fingers.

links.description: Murawarri activist and filmmaker Essie Coffey was one of the first Indigenous people to document the blak experience on film. Through My Survival as an Aboriginal she exposed how First Peoples were marginalised in all aspects of their lives, from school to wider society.

constellations_other.name: Keep the fire burning
constellations_other.description: Yanmeeyarr, meaning ‘flickering in firelight’, shares how light and shadow are at the core of the moving image. It reflects the past, present and future of stories told by First Peoples utilising these elements, as well as bringing to light stories that have, for too long, been kept in the dark.

key_work.title: Electric sound
key_work.brief_description: The wave of electric sound from the 40s onwards transformed not just how people watched movies and how they identified genre, but how they listened to it as well. The otherworldly chords of the theremin became indelibly linked to science fiction.

links.description: Composer Peter Best also used newly invented electronic instruments for the haunting soundtrack of Gillian Armstrong’s High Tide. Relying on the Fairlight CMI, the first digital synthesiser and sampler, the film’s score was one of the first produced entirely with a sampling synthesiser.

recommendations.quote: I watched this through a keyhole into the locked TV room where my older siblings watched a bootleg version. When I was caught, the VHS tape was destroyed but the damage was done; I've been an insomniac since.

links.description: Charles Bernstein previously harnessed the eerie and menacing quality of electric sound instruments in his score for A Nightmare of Elm Street. Using acoustic instruments, reverb and synth, he created the perfect soundtrack for a horror movie that blurs the line between nightmares and reality.

key_work.title: Spotlights: Rachel Perkins
key_work.brief_description: An Australian film and television director, producer, and screenwriter. She is known for her films Radiance (1998), One Night the Moon (2001), Bran Nue Dae (2009) and Jasper Jones (2017). Rachel discusses the merits of film and television from an Indigenous perspective, particularly in relation to audience.

constellations_other.name: Storytime animated
constellations_other.description: Abra Cadabra was the world's first stereoscopic 3D film, but animators and filmmakers had experimented with the technology far earlier and continue to use other older techniques like stop-motion animation.

links.description: The hauntingly beautiful Coraline also employed 3D to construct a greater sense of wonder and depth into the mysterious ‘other world’. Caroline’s real world appears slightly flat and cramped while the other world is glossier and endless heightened by incorporating 3D technology.

results.description: Fascination with the royal family has persisted over the years, as seen through newsreels, documentaries, films, TV shows, tabloid news and satire.

key_work.title: Royal tour of Queen Elizabeth II
key_work.brief_description: In 1954, huge crowds greeted Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip on her Australian tour, all captured by newsreel camera crews who followed the royals around Australia. Footage was also made into the first Australian colour documentary, The Queen in Australia.

constellations_other.name: Spectacle
constellations_other.description: The moving image has captured some of history’s biggest moments. From newsreel shorts in cinemas before the show to the arrival of TV, nightly news and the 24-hour news cycle to social media, news has become a spectacle.

results.name: The war effort on film
results.description: Newsreel and documentaries were used as propaganda for the war effort by all sides during WWII, many of them made by major film studios, directors and actors.

key_work.title: Kokoda Front Line
key_work.brief_description: This newsreel gave Australians the first glimpse of fighting on the Kokoda Trail and was used as propaganda. Photographer Damien Parer and director Ken G Hall restaged several combat scenes and asked viewers to join the war effort. In 1943, it won Australia’s first Oscar.

constellations_primary.description: Newsreel and documentaries were used as propaganda for the war effort by all sides during WWII, many of them made by major film studios, directors and actors.

constellations_other.name: Spectacle
constellations_other.description: The moving image has captured some of history’s biggest moments. From newsreel shorts in cinemas before the show to the arrival of TV, nightly news and the 24-hour news cycle to social media, news has become a spectacle.

end.title: Why We Fight: Prelude to War
end.creator_credit: Anatole Litvak, Frank Capra, War Activities Committee of the Motion Pictures Industry, Anthony Veiller and Eric Knight
end.brief_description: Prelude to War was the first film of Frank Capra’s Why We Fight propaganda film series, commissioned by the Pentagon and George C. Marshall. It was made to convince American troops of the necessity of combating the Axis Powers during World War II. This film examines the differences between democratic and fascist states.

constellations_other.name: The war effort on film
constellations_other.description: Newsreel and documentaries were used as propaganda for the war effort by all sides during WWII, many of them made by major film studios, directors and actors.

links.description: Like Kokoda Front Line!, Why We Fight: Prelude to War also won an Oscar for Best Documentary in 1943. Directed by Frank Capra, a Hollywood director, the film was the first in a series of seven that sought to both inform and inspire American audiences.

end.title: Triumph of the Will
end.creator_credit: Leni Riefenstahl, Leni Riefenstahl-Produktion, Reichspropagandaleitung der NSDAP, Eberhard Taubert and Walter Ruttmann
end.brief_description: Filmmaker Leni Riefenstahl’s controversial masterwork is an artful work of propaganda showcasing German chancellor and Nazi Party leader Adolf Hitler at the 1934 Nuremberg Rally. Edited from over 60 hours’ worth of raw footage shot over the course of the rally’s four days, the film is visually remarkable in the way it captures the event’s enormous scale.

constellations_other.name: The war effort on film
constellations_other.description: Newsreel and documentaries were used as propaganda for the war effort by all sides during WWII, many of them made by major film studios, directors and actors.

links.description: Frank Capra described his shock at watching Leni Riefenstahl’s The Triumph of the Will, which served as propaganda for the Nazi cause. Capra made his films in direct response to the persuasive techniques of the German film.

end.title: Winning Your Wings
end.creator_credit: John Huston, Owen Crump, Jack L. Warner, U.S. Army Air Forces and Warner Bros. Pictures
end.brief_description: Winning Your Wings is a 1942 short American World War II recruitment film produced by Warner Bros. Studios for the US Army Air Forces, starring Jimmy Stewart. It was aimed at young men who were thinking about joining the Air Force.

constellations_other.name: The war effort on film
constellations_other.description: Newsreel and documentaries were used as propaganda for the war effort by all sides during WWII, many of them made by major film studios, directors and actors.

links.description: Hollywood actors were also called upon to star in American propaganda films. In the short recruitment film Winning Your Wings, James Stewart plays a dashing pilot encouraging audiences to join the air force.

end.title: Kokoda
end.creator_credit: Alister Grierson, John Lonie, Catriona Hughes, Leesa Kahn, Australian Film Finance Corporation, GFN Productions and Pacific Film and Television Commission
end.brief_description: A bitter battle is fought between Australian and Japanese soldiers along the Kokoda trail in New Guinea during World War II.

constellations_other.name: The war effort on film
constellations_other.description: Newsreel and documentaries were used as propaganda for the war effort by all sides during WWII, many of them made by major film studios, directors and actors.

links.description: The experiences of Australian troops on the Kokoda Trail were dramatised in the feature film Kokoda, showing the chaotic and grim realities of frontline warfare. Many scenes were shot with handheld cameras, as the original war photography would have been.
